1‚Üí"""Preprocessing module to convert JSONL traces to visualization-ready JSON."""
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üíimport hashlib
     4‚Üíimport json
     5‚Üífrom dataclasses import asdict, dataclass, field
     6‚Üífrom datetime import datetime
     7‚Üífrom pathlib import Path
     8‚Üífrom typing import Any, Literal
     9‚Üí
    10‚ÜíApiFormat = Literal["auto", "openai", "claude"]
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí@dataclass
    14‚Üíclass CookedMessage:
    15‚Üí    """Deduplicated message with stable ID."""
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí    id: str
    18‚Üí    role: str  # "system" | "user" | "tool_use" | "tool_result" | "assistant"
    19‚Üí    content: str
    20‚Üí    tool_calls: list[dict] | None = None
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí@dataclass
    24‚Üíclass CookedTool:
    25‚Üí    """Deduplicated tool definition with stable ID."""
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí    id: str
    28‚Üí    name: str
    29‚Üí    description: str
    30‚Üí    parameters: dict
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí@dataclass
    34‚Üíclass CookedRequest:
    35‚Üí    """A single request/response pair with references to messages and tools."""
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí    id: str
    38‚Üí    parent_id: str | None
    39‚Üí    timestamp: int  # Unix milliseconds
    40‚Üí    request_messages: list[str]  # Message IDs
    41‚Üí    response_message: str  # Message ID
    42‚Üí    model: str
    43‚Üí    tools: list[str]  # Tool IDs
    44‚Üí    duration_ms: int
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí@dataclass
    48‚Üíclass CookedOutput:
    49‚Üí    """Final output structure for visualization."""
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí    messages: list[CookedMessage] = field(default_factory=list)
    52‚Üí    tools: list[CookedTool] = field(default_factory=list)
    53‚Üí    requests: list[CookedRequest] = field(default_factory=list)
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí    def to_dict(self) -> dict[str, Any]:
    56‚Üí        """Convert to dictionary for JSON serialization."""
    57‚Üí        return {
    58‚Üí            "messages": [asdict(m) for m in self.messages],
    59‚Üí            "tools": [asdict(t) for t in self.tools],
    60‚Üí            "requests": [asdict(r) for r in self.requests],
    61‚Üí        }
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üídef _compute_message_hash(role: str, content: str, tool_calls: list[dict] | None) -> str:
    65‚Üí    """Compute stable hash for message deduplication."""
    66‚Üí    data = {
    67‚Üí        "role": role,
    68‚Üí        "content": content,
    69‚Üí        "tool_calls": tool_calls,
    70‚Üí    }
    71‚Üí    json_str = json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True, ensure_ascii=False)
    72‚Üí    return hashlib.sha256(json_str.encode()).hexdigest()[:16]
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üídef _compute_tool_hash(name: str, description: str, parameters: dict) -> str:
    76‚Üí    """Compute stable hash for tool deduplication."""
    77‚Üí    data = {
    78‚Üí        "name": name,
    79‚Üí        "description": description,
    80‚Üí        "parameters": parameters,
    81‚Üí    }
    82‚Üí    json_str = json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True, ensure_ascii=False)
    83‚Üí    return hashlib.sha256(json_str.encode()).hexdigest()[:16]
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí
    86‚Üídef _map_role(role: str, tool_calls: list[dict] | None) -> str:
    87‚Üí    """Map original role to visualization role."""
    88‚Üí    if role == "assistant" and tool_calls:
    89‚Üí        return "tool_use"
    90‚Üí    if role == "tool":
    91‚Üí        return "tool_result"
    92‚Üí    return role
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üídef _parse_openai_sse(sse_lines: list[str]) -> dict:
    96‚Üí    """Parse OpenAI SSE lines into a response dict.
    97‚Üí
    98‚Üí    OpenAI format:
    99‚Üí        data: {"id": "xxx", "model": "gpt-4", "choices": [{"delta": {"content": "Hi"}}]}
   100‚Üí        data: [DONE]
   101‚Üí    """
   102‚Üí    response_id = None
   103‚Üí    model = None
   104‚Üí    content_parts = []
   105‚Üí    tool_calls: dict[int, dict] = {}  # index -> {name, arguments}
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí    for line in sse_lines:
   108‚Üí        if not line.startswith("data: "):
   109‚Üí            continue
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí        data = line[6:]
   112‚Üí        if data == "[DONE]":
   113‚Üí            continue
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí        try:
   116‚Üí            chunk = json.loads(data)
   117‚Üí        except json.JSONDecodeError:
   118‚Üí            continue
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí        # Extract metadata
   121‚Üí        if response_id is None:
   122‚Üí            response_id = chunk.get("id")
   123‚Üí        if model is None:
   124‚Üí            model = chunk.get("model")
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí        # Extract content delta
   127‚Üí        choices = chunk.get("choices", [])
   128‚Üí        if not choices:
   129‚Üí            continue
   130‚Üí
   131‚Üí        delta = choices[0].get("delta", {})
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí        # Text content
   134‚Üí        content = delta.get("content")
   135‚Üí        if content:
   136‚Üí            content_parts.append(content)
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí        # Tool calls
   139‚Üí        delta_tool_calls = delta.get("tool_calls", [])
   140‚Üí        for tc in delta_tool_calls:
   141‚Üí            idx = tc.get("index", 0)
   142‚Üí            if idx not in tool_calls:
   143‚Üí                tool_calls[idx] = {"id": "", "name": "", "arguments": ""}
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí            if "id" in tc:
   146‚Üí                tool_calls[idx]["id"] = tc["id"]
   147‚Üí            if "function" in tc:
   148‚Üí                func = tc["function"]
   149‚Üí                if "name" in func:
   150‚Üí                    tool_calls[idx]["name"] = func["name"]
   151‚Üí                if "arguments" in func:
   152‚Üí                    tool_calls[idx]["arguments"] += func["arguments"]
   153‚Üí
   154‚Üí    # Build response in OpenAI format
   155‚Üí    message: dict = {
   156‚Üí        "role": "assistant",
   157‚Üí        "content": "".join(content_parts),
   158‚Üí    }
   159‚Üí
   160‚Üí    if tool_calls:
   161‚Üí        message["tool_calls"] = [
   162‚Üí            {
   163‚Üí                "id": tc["id"],
   164‚Üí                "type": "function",
   165‚Üí                "function": {"name": tc["name"], "arguments": tc["arguments"]},
   166‚Üí            }
   167‚Üí            for tc in sorted(tool_calls.values(), key=lambda x: x.get("id", ""))
   168‚Üí        ]
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí    return {
   171‚Üí        "id": response_id,
   172‚Üí        "model": model,
   173‚Üí        "choices": [{"message": message}],
   174‚Üí    }
   175‚Üí
   176‚Üí
   177‚Üídef _parse_claude_sse(sse_lines: list[str]) -> dict:
   178‚Üí    """Parse Claude SSE lines into a response dict.
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí    Claude format:
   181‚Üí        event: message_start
   182‚Üí        data: {"type": "message_start", "message": {"id": "xxx", "model": "..."}}
   183‚Üí
   184‚Üí        event: content_block_delta
   185‚Üí        data: {"type": "content_block_delta", "delta": {"type": "text_delta", "text": "Hi"}}
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üí        event: message_stop
   188‚Üí        data: {"type": "message_stop"}
   189‚Üí    """
   190‚Üí    response_id = None
   191‚Üí    model = None
   192‚Üí    content_blocks: dict[int, dict] = {}  # index -> {type, text/name/input}
   193‚Üí    stop_reason = None
   194‚Üí
   195‚Üí    for line in sse_lines:
   196‚Üí        if not line.startswith("data: "):
   197‚Üí            continue
   198‚Üí
   199‚Üí        data = line[6:]
   200‚Üí        try:
   201‚Üí            chunk = json.loads(data)
   202‚Üí        except json.JSONDecodeError:
   203‚Üí            continue
   204‚Üí
   205‚Üí        event_type = chunk.get("type", "")
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí        if event_type == "message_start":
   208‚Üí            message = chunk.get("message", {})
   209‚Üí            response_id = message.get("id")
   210‚Üí            model = message.get("model")
   211‚Üí
   212‚Üí        elif event_type == "content_block_start":
   213‚Üí            index = chunk.get("index", 0)
   214‚Üí            block = chunk.get("content_block", {})
   215‚Üí            block_type = block.get("type", "text")
   216‚Üí            content_blocks[index] = {
   217‚Üí                "type": block_type,
   218‚Üí                "text": block.get("text", ""),
   219‚Üí                "name": block.get("name", ""),
   220‚Üí                "input": "",  # Will be accumulated
   221‚Üí            }
   222‚Üí
   223‚Üí        elif event_type == "content_block_delta":
   224‚Üí            index = chunk.get("index", 0)
   225‚Üí            delta = chunk.get("delta", {})
   226‚Üí            delta_type = delta.get("type", "")
   227‚Üí
   228‚Üí            if index not in content_blocks:
   229‚Üí                content_blocks[index] = {"type": "text", "text": "", "name": "", "input": ""}
   230‚Üí
   231‚Üí            if delta_type == "text_delta":
   232‚Üí                content_blocks[index]["text"] += delta.get("text", "")
   233‚Üí            elif delta_type == "thinking_delta":
   234‚Üí                content_blocks[index]["text"] += delta.get("thinking", "")
   235‚Üí            elif delta_type == "input_json_delta":
   236‚Üí                content_blocks[index]["input"] += delta.get("partial_json", "")
   237‚Üí
   238‚Üí        elif event_type == "message_delta":
   239‚Üí            delta = chunk.get("delta", {})
   240‚Üí            stop_reason = delta.get("stop_reason")
   241‚Üí
   242‚Üí    # Build response in Claude format
   243‚Üí    content = []
   244‚Üí    for idx in sorted(content_blocks.keys()):
   245‚Üí        block = content_blocks[idx]
   246‚Üí        block_type = block["type"]
   247‚Üí
   248‚Üí        if block_type == "text":
   249‚Üí            content.append({"type": "text", "text": block["text"]})
   250‚Üí        elif block_type == "thinking":
   251‚Üí            content.append({"type": "thinking", "thinking": block["text"]})
   252‚Üí        elif block_type == "tool_use":
   253‚Üí            input_data = {}
   254‚Üí            if block["input"]:
   255‚Üí                try:
   256‚Üí                    input_data = json.loads(block["input"])
   257‚Üí                except json.JSONDecodeError:
   258‚Üí                    input_data = {"raw": block["input"]}
   259‚Üí            content.append(
   260‚Üí                {
   261‚Üí                    "type": "tool_use",
   262‚Üí                    "name": block["name"],
   263‚Üí                    "input": input_data,
   264‚Üí                }
   265‚Üí            )
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí    return {
   268‚Üí        "id": response_id,
   269‚Üí        "model": model,
   270‚Üí        "content": content,
   271‚Üí        "stop_reason": stop_reason,
   272‚Üí    }
   273‚Üí
   274‚Üí
   275‚Üídef _is_claude_sse(sse_lines: list[str]) -> bool:
   276‚Üí    """Detect if SSE lines are in Claude format."""
   277‚Üí    for line in sse_lines:
   278‚Üí        if line.startswith("data: "):
   279‚Üí            data = line[6:]
   280‚Üí            try:
   281‚Üí                chunk = json.loads(data)
   282‚Üí                # Claude events have a "type" field
   283‚Üí                if "type" in chunk and chunk["type"] in (
   284‚Üí                    "message_start",
   285‚Üí                    "content_block_start",
   286‚Üí                    "content_block_delta",
   287‚Üí                    "message_delta",
   288‚Üí                    "message_stop",
   289‚Üí                ):
   290‚Üí                    return True
   291‚Üí                # OpenAI events have "choices" field
   292‚Üí                if "choices" in chunk:
   293‚Üí                    return False
   294‚Üí            except json.JSONDecodeError:
   295‚Üí                continue
   296‚Üí    return False
   297‚Üí
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üídef _parse_tool_calls(tool_calls: list[dict] | None) -> list[dict] | None:
   300‚Üí    """Parse tool_calls, flattening to {name, arguments} format for frontend."""
   301‚Üí    if not tool_calls:
   302‚Üí        return None
   303‚Üí
   304‚Üí    parsed = []
   305‚Üí    for tc in tool_calls:
   306‚Üí        # Extract function name and arguments from OpenAI format
   307‚Üí        if "function" in tc and isinstance(tc["function"], dict):
   308‚Üí            func = tc["function"]
   309‚Üí            name = func.get("name", "")
   310‚Üí            arguments = func.get("arguments", {})
   311‚Üí
   312‚Üí            # Decode JSON arguments string to dict
   313‚Üí            if isinstance(arguments, str):
   314‚Üí                try:
   315‚Üí                    arguments = json.loads(arguments)
   316‚Üí                except json.JSONDecodeError:
   317‚Üí                    arguments = {"raw": arguments}  # Keep as raw if not valid JSON
   318‚Üí
   319‚Üí            parsed.append({"name": name, "arguments": arguments})
   320‚Üí        else:
   321‚Üí            # Already flat format or unknown structure
   322‚Üí            parsed.append(tc)
   323‚Üí    return parsed
   324‚Üí
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üídef _iso_to_unix_ms(iso_str: str) -> int:
   327‚Üí    """Convert ISO timestamp to Unix milliseconds."""
   328‚Üí    # Handle various ISO formats
   329‚Üí    iso_str = iso_str.replace("Z", "+00:00")
   330‚Üí    try:
   331‚Üí        dt = datetime.fromisoformat(iso_str)
   332‚Üí        return int(dt.timestamp() * 1000)
   333‚Üí    except ValueError:
   334‚Üí        return 0
   335‚Üí
   336‚Üí
   337‚Üídef _detect_api_format(record: dict) -> str:
   338‚Üí    """Detect whether record is Claude or OpenAI format."""
   339‚Üí    request = record.get("request", {})
   340‚Üí    response = record.get("response", {})
   341‚Üí
   342‚Üí    # Check streaming response SSE format
   343‚Üí    if response and response.get("stream") and "sse_lines" in response:
   344‚Üí        if _is_claude_sse(response["sse_lines"]):
   345‚Üí            return "claude"
   346‚Üí        return "openai"
   347‚Üí
   348‚Üí    # Claude indicators: system field is a list of blocks
   349‚Üí    if "system" in request and isinstance(request.get("system"), list):
   350‚Üí        return "claude"
   351‚Üí
   352‚Üí    # Claude tools have input_schema instead of function.parameters
   353‚Üí    tools = request.get("tools", [])
   354‚Üí    if tools and isinstance(tools[0], dict) and "input_schema" in tools[0]:
   355‚Üí        return "claude"
   356‚Üí
   357‚Üí    # Check for Claude content block types in messages
   358‚Üí    for msg in request.get("messages", []):
   359‚Üí        content = msg.get("content")
   360‚Üí        if isinstance(content, list):
   361‚Üí            for block in content:
   362‚Üí                if isinstance(block, dict) and block.get("type") in (
   363‚Üí                    "tool_use",
   364‚Üí                    "tool_result",
   365‚Üí                    "thinking",
   366‚Üí                ):
   367‚Üí                    return "claude"
   368‚Üí
   369‚Üí    return "openai"
   370‚Üí
   371‚Üí
   372‚Üíclass TraceCooker:
   373‚Üí    """Processes trace records into deduplicated visualization format."""
   374‚Üí
   375‚Üí    def __init__(self):
   376‚Üí        self.message_hash_to_id: dict[str, str] = {}
   377‚Üí        self.tool_hash_to_id: dict[str, str] = {}
   378‚Üí        self.messages: list[CookedMessage] = []
   379‚Üí        self.tools: list[CookedTool] = []
   380‚Üí        self.requests: list[CookedRequest] = []
   381‚Üí        self._message_counter = 0
   382‚Üí        self._tool_counter = 0
   383‚Üí
   384‚Üí    def _get_or_create_message(self, role: str, content: str, tool_calls: list[dict] | None) -> str:
   385‚Üí        """Get existing message ID or create new message, returns ID."""
   386‚Üí        mapped_role = _map_role(role, tool_calls)
   387‚Üí        parsed_tool_calls = _parse_tool_calls(tool_calls)
   388‚Üí        content = content or ""
   389‚Üí
   390‚Üí        msg_hash = _compute_message_hash(mapped_role, content, parsed_tool_calls)
   391‚Üí
   392‚Üí        if msg_hash in self.message_hash_to_id:
   393‚Üí            return self.message_hash_to_id[msg_hash]
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí        msg_id = f"m{self._message_counter}"
   396‚Üí        self._message_counter += 1
   397‚Üí
   398‚Üí        msg = CookedMessage(
   399‚Üí            id=msg_id,
   400‚Üí            role=mapped_role,
   401‚Üí            content=content,
   402‚Üí            tool_calls=parsed_tool_calls,
   403‚Üí        )
   404‚Üí        self.messages.append(msg)
   405‚Üí        self.message_hash_to_id[msg_hash] = msg_id
   406‚Üí        return msg_id
   407‚Üí
   408‚Üí    def _get_or_create_tool(self, name: str, description: str, parameters: dict) -> str:
   409‚Üí        """Get existing tool ID or create new tool, returns ID."""
   410‚Üí        tool_hash = _compute_tool_hash(name, description, parameters)
   411‚Üí
   412‚Üí        if tool_hash in self.tool_hash_to_id:
   413‚Üí            return self.tool_hash_to_id[tool_hash]
   414‚Üí
   415‚Üí        tool_id = f"t{self._tool_counter}"
   416‚Üí        self._tool_counter += 1
   417‚Üí
   418‚Üí        tool = CookedTool(
   419‚Üí            id=tool_id,
   420‚Üí            name=name,
   421‚Üí            description=description,
   422‚Üí            parameters=parameters,
   423‚Üí        )
   424‚Üí        self.tools.append(tool)
   425‚Üí        self.tool_hash_to_id[tool_hash] = tool_id
   426‚Üí        return tool_id
   427‚Üí
   428‚Üí    def _process_request_messages(self, messages: list[dict]) -> list[str]:
   429‚Üí        """Process request messages and return list of message IDs.
   430‚Üí
   431‚Üí        Handles content that can be either a string or an array.
   432‚Üí        When content is an array, each element is expanded into a separate message.
   433‚Üí        """
   434‚Üí        msg_ids = []
   435‚Üí        for msg in messages:
   436‚Üí            role = msg.get("role", "")
   437‚Üí            content = msg.get("content", "")
   438‚Üí            tool_calls = msg.get("tool_calls")
   439‚Üí
   440‚Üí            # Handle content as array - expand into multiple messages
   441‚Üí            if isinstance(content, list):
   442‚Üí                for item in content:
   443‚Üí                    item_content = self._extract_content_from_item(item)
   444‚Üí                    msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, item_content, None)
   445‚Üí                    msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   446‚Üí                # If there are tool_calls, add a separate message for them
   447‚Üí                if tool_calls:
   448‚Üí                    msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, "", tool_calls)
   449‚Üí                    msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   450‚Üí            else:
   451‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, content, tool_calls)
   452‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   453‚Üí        return msg_ids
   454‚Üí
   455‚Üí    def _extract_content_from_item(self, item: str | dict) -> str:
   456‚Üí        """Extract content string from a content array item.
   457‚Üí
   458‚Üí        Handles both plain strings and structured content objects like:
   459‚Üí        - {"type": "text", "text": "..."}
   460‚Üí        - {"type": "image_url", "image_url": {"url": "..."}}
   461‚Üí        """
   462‚Üí        if isinstance(item, str):
   463‚Üí            return item
   464‚Üí        if isinstance(item, dict):
   465‚Üí            # Text content block
   466‚Üí            if item.get("type") == "text":
   467‚Üí                return item.get("text", "")
   468‚Üí            # Image URL content block
   469‚Üí            if item.get("type") == "image_url":
   470‚Üí                image_url = item.get("image_url", {})
   471‚Üí                url = image_url.get("url", "") if isinstance(image_url, dict) else str(image_url)
   472‚Üí                # Truncate base64 data URLs for display
   473‚Üí                if url.startswith("data:"):
   474‚Üí                    return "[image: base64 data]"
   475‚Üí                return f"[image: {url}]"
   476‚Üí            # Other types - serialize as JSON
   477‚Üí            return json.dumps(item, ensure_ascii=False)
   478‚Üí        return str(item)
   479‚Üí
   480‚Üí    def _process_response_message(self, response: dict | None, error: str | None) -> str:
   481‚Üí        """Process response and return message ID."""
   482‚Üí        if error:
   483‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", f"Error: {error}", None)
   484‚Üí
   485‚Üí        if not response:
   486‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", "", None)
   487‚Üí
   488‚Üí        # Handle streaming response - parse SSE lines first
   489‚Üí        if response.get("stream") and "sse_lines" in response:
   490‚Üí            sse_lines = response["sse_lines"]
   491‚Üí            response = _parse_openai_sse(sse_lines)
   492‚Üí
   493‚Üí        choices = response.get("choices", [])
   494‚Üí        if not choices:
   495‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", "", None)
   496‚Üí
   497‚Üí        message = choices[0].get("message", {})
   498‚Üí        role = message.get("role", "assistant")
   499‚Üí        content = message.get("content", "")
   500‚Üí        tool_calls = message.get("tool_calls")
   501‚Üí
   502‚Üí        return self._get_or_create_message(role, content, tool_calls)
   503‚Üí
   504‚Üí    def _process_tools(self, tools: list[dict] | None) -> list[str]:
   505‚Üí        """Process tool definitions and return list of tool IDs."""
   506‚Üí        if not tools:
   507‚Üí            return []
   508‚Üí
   509‚Üí        tool_ids = []
   510‚Üí        for tool in tools:
   511‚Üí            if tool.get("type") == "function":
   512‚Üí                func = tool.get("function", {})
   513‚Üí                name = func.get("name", "")
   514‚Üí                description = func.get("description", "")
   515‚Üí                parameters = func.get("parameters", {})
   516‚Üí
   517‚Üí                tool_id = self._get_or_create_tool(name, description, parameters)
   518‚Üí                tool_ids.append(tool_id)
   519‚Üí        return tool_ids
   520‚Üí
   521‚Üí    # ========== Claude API format processing methods ==========
   522‚Üí
   523‚Üí    def _process_claude_system(self, system: list[dict] | None) -> list[str]:
   524‚Üí        """Process Claude's system field into system message IDs."""
   525‚Üí        if not system:
   526‚Üí            return []
   527‚Üí
   528‚Üí        msg_ids = []
   529‚Üí        for block in system:
   530‚Üí            if isinstance(block, dict) and block.get("type") == "text":
   531‚Üí                content = block.get("text", "")
   532‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message("system", content, None)
   533‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   534‚Üí            elif isinstance(block, str):
   535‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message("system", block, None)
   536‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   537‚Üí        return msg_ids
   538‚Üí
   539‚Üí    def _process_claude_request_messages(
   540‚Üí        self, messages: list[dict], system: list[dict] | None
   541‚Üí    ) -> list[str]:
   542‚Üí        """Process Claude request messages and return list of message IDs."""
   543‚Üí        msg_ids = []
   544‚Üí
   545‚Üí        # First add system messages
   546‚Üí        msg_ids.extend(self._process_claude_system(system))
   547‚Üí
   548‚Üí        for msg in messages:
   549‚Üí            role = msg.get("role", "")
   550‚Üí            content = msg.get("content")
   551‚Üí
   552‚Üí            # Handle content as string (simple case)
   553‚Üí            if isinstance(content, str):
   554‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, content, None)
   555‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   556‚Üí                continue
   557‚Üí
   558‚Üí            # Handle content as array of blocks
   559‚Üí            if isinstance(content, list):
   560‚Üí                msg_ids.extend(self._process_claude_content_blocks(role, content))
   561‚Üí
   562‚Üí        return msg_ids
   563‚Üí
   564‚Üí    def _process_claude_content_blocks(self, role: str, blocks: list[dict]) -> list[str]:
   565‚Üí        """Process Claude content blocks and return message IDs.
   566‚Üí
   567‚Üí        Each text block becomes a separate message (consistent with OpenAI handling).
   568‚Üí        Thinking blocks are prefixed to the next text block.
   569‚Üí        Tool use blocks are collected into a single tool_use message.
   570‚Üí        Tool result blocks become separate tool_result messages.
   571‚Üí        """
   572‚Üí        msg_ids = []
   573‚Üí        tool_calls = []
   574‚Üí        pending_thinking = ""
   575‚Üí
   576‚Üí        for block in blocks:
   577‚Üí            if not isinstance(block, dict):
   578‚Üí                # Plain string - create message
   579‚Üí                content = str(block)
   580‚Üí                if pending_thinking:
   581‚Üí                    content = f"thinking:\n{pending_thinking}\n\n{content}"
   582‚Üí                    pending_thinking = ""
   583‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, content, None)
   584‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   585‚Üí                continue
   586‚Üí
   587‚Üí            block_type = block.get("type", "")
   588‚Üí
   589‚Üí            if block_type == "text":
   590‚Üí                # Each text block becomes a separate message
   591‚Üí                content = block.get("text", "")
   592‚Üí                if pending_thinking:
   593‚Üí                    content = f"thinking:\n{pending_thinking}\n\n{content}"
   594‚Üí                    pending_thinking = ""
   595‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, content, None)
   596‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   597‚Üí
   598‚Üí            elif block_type == "thinking":
   599‚Üí                # Buffer thinking to prepend to next text block
   600‚Üí                pending_thinking = block.get("thinking", "")
   601‚Üí
   602‚Üí            elif block_type == "tool_use":
   603‚Üí                # Collect tool calls
   604‚Üí                tool_calls.append(
   605‚Üí                    {
   606‚Üí                        "name": block.get("name", ""),
   607‚Üí                        "arguments": block.get("input", {}),
   608‚Üí                    }
   609‚Üí                )
   610‚Üí
   611‚Üí            elif block_type == "tool_result":
   612‚Üí                # Create separate message with tool_result role
   613‚Üí                result_content = block.get("content", "")
   614‚Üí                if isinstance(result_content, list):
   615‚Üí                    # Handle content as array (e.g., multiple text blocks)
   616‚Üí                    result_content = "\n".join(
   617‚Üí                        b.get("text", str(b)) if isinstance(b, dict) else str(b)
   618‚Üí                        for b in result_content
   619‚Üí                    )
   620‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message("tool_result", str(result_content), None)
   621‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   622‚Üí
   623‚Üí            elif block_type == "image":
   624‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, "[image]", None)
   625‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   626‚Üí
   627‚Üí            else:
   628‚Üí                # Unknown block type - serialize as JSON
   629‚Üí                content = json.dumps(block, ensure_ascii=False)
   630‚Üí                msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, content, None)
   631‚Üí                msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   632‚Üí
   633‚Üí        # Create tool_use message if there are tool calls
   634‚Üí        if tool_calls:
   635‚Üí            # If there's pending thinking, include it
   636‚Üí            content = ""
   637‚Üí            if pending_thinking:
   638‚Üí                content = f"thinking:\n{pending_thinking}"
   639‚Üí                pending_thinking = ""
   640‚Üí            msg_id = self._get_or_create_message("tool_use", content, tool_calls)
   641‚Üí            msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   642‚Üí        elif pending_thinking:
   643‚Üí            # Orphan thinking block (no following text) - create standalone message
   644‚Üí            msg_id = self._get_or_create_message(role, f"thinking:\n{pending_thinking}", None)
   645‚Üí            msg_ids.append(msg_id)
   646‚Üí
   647‚Üí        return msg_ids
   648‚Üí
   649‚Üí    def _process_claude_response(self, response: dict | None, error: str | None) -> str:
   650‚Üí        """Process Claude response and return message ID."""
   651‚Üí        if error:
   652‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", f"Error: {error}", None)
   653‚Üí
   654‚Üí        if not response:
   655‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", "", None)
   656‚Üí
   657‚Üí        # Handle streaming response - parse SSE lines first
   658‚Üí        if response.get("stream") and "sse_lines" in response:
   659‚Üí            sse_lines = response["sse_lines"]
   660‚Üí            response = _parse_claude_sse(sse_lines)
   661‚Üí
   662‚Üí        content = response.get("content", [])
   663‚Üí        if not content:
   664‚Üí            return self._get_or_create_message("assistant", "", None)
   665‚Üí
   666‚Üí        text_parts = []
   667‚Üí        tool_calls = []
   668‚Üí
   669‚Üí        for block in content:
   670‚Üí            if not isinstance(block, dict):
   671‚Üí                text_parts.append(str(block))
   672‚Üí                continue
   673‚Üí
   674‚Üí            block_type = block.get("type", "")
   675‚Üí
   676‚Üí            if block_type == "text":
   677‚Üí                text_parts.append(block.get("text", ""))
   678‚Üí
   679‚Üí            elif block_type == "thinking":
   680‚Üí                thinking_text = block.get("thinking", "")
   681‚Üí                if thinking_text:
   682‚Üí                    text_parts.insert(0, f"thinking:\n{thinking_text}\n")
   683‚Üí
   684‚Üí            elif block_type == "tool_use":
   685‚Üí                tool_calls.append(
   686‚Üí                    {
   687‚Üí                        "name": block.get("name", ""),
   688‚Üí                        "arguments": block.get("input", {}),
   689‚Üí                    }
   690‚Üí                )
   691‚Üí
   692‚Üí        combined_text = "".join(text_parts).strip()
   693‚Üí        return self._get_or_create_message(
   694‚Üí            "assistant", combined_text, tool_calls if tool_calls else None
   695‚Üí        )
   696‚Üí
   697‚Üí    def _process_claude_tools(self, tools: list[dict] | None) -> list[str]:
   698‚Üí        """Process Claude tool definitions and return list of tool IDs."""
   699‚Üí        if not tools:
   700‚Üí            return []
   701‚Üí
   702‚Üí        tool_ids = []
   703‚Üí        for tool in tools:
   704‚Üí            name = tool.get("name", "")
   705‚Üí            description = tool.get("description", "")
   706‚Üí            # Claude uses input_schema instead of parameters
   707‚Üí            parameters = tool.get("input_schema", {})
   708‚Üí
   709‚Üí            tool_id = self._get_or_create_tool(name, description, parameters)
   710‚Üí            tool_ids.append(tool_id)
   711‚Üí        return tool_ids
   712‚Üí
   713‚Üí    def _process_record_claude(self, record: dict) -> CookedRequest:
   714‚Üí        """Process a single Claude API trace record."""
   715‚Üí        request = record.get("request", {})
   716‚Üí        response = record.get("response")
   717‚Üí        error = record.get("error")
   718‚Üí
   719‚Üí        # Process request messages (with system)
   720‚Üí        messages = request.get("messages", [])
   721‚Üí        system = request.get("system")
   722‚Üí        request_msg_ids = self._process_claude_request_messages(messages, system)
   723‚Üí
   724‚Üí        # Process response message
   725‚Üí        response_msg_id = self._process_claude_response(response, error)
   726‚Üí
   727‚Üí        # Process tools
   728‚Üí        tools = request.get("tools", [])
   729‚Üí        tool_ids = self._process_claude_tools(tools)
   730‚Üí
   731‚Üí        # Create request record
   732‚Üí        record_id = record.get("id", "")
   733‚Üí        timestamp = _iso_to_unix_ms(record.get("timestamp", ""))
   734‚Üí        model = request.get("model", "")
   735‚Üí        duration_ms = record.get("duration_ms", 0)
   736‚Üí
   737‚Üí        return CookedRequest(
   738‚Üí            id=record_id,
   739‚Üí            parent_id=None,
   740‚Üí            timestamp=timestamp,
   741‚Üí            request_messages=request_msg_ids,
   742‚Üí            response_message=response_msg_id,
   743‚Üí            model=model,
   744‚Üí            tools=tool_ids,
   745‚Üí            duration_ms=duration_ms,
   746‚Üí        )
   747‚Üí
   748‚Üí    def _process_record(self, record: dict, api_format: str = "auto") -> CookedRequest:
   749‚Üí        """Process a single trace record, returns CookedRequest (parent_id not set)."""
   750‚Üí        # Determine format
   751‚Üí        if api_format == "auto":
   752‚Üí            detected_format = _detect_api_format(record)
   753‚Üí        else:
   754‚Üí            detected_format = api_format
   755‚Üí
   756‚Üí        # Dispatch to format-specific handler
   757‚Üí        if detected_format == "claude":
   758‚Üí            return self._process_record_claude(record)
   759‚Üí
   760‚Üí        # OpenAI format (default)
   761‚Üí        request = record.get("request", {})
   762‚Üí        response = record.get("response")
   763‚Üí        error = record.get("error")
   764‚Üí
   765‚Üí        # Process request messages
   766‚Üí        messages = request.get("messages", [])
   767‚Üí        request_msg_ids = self._process_request_messages(messages)
   768‚Üí
   769‚Üí        # Process response message
   770‚Üí        response_msg_id = self._process_response_message(response, error)
   771‚Üí
   772‚Üí        # Process tools
   773‚Üí        tools = request.get("tools", [])
   774‚Üí        tool_ids = self._process_tools(tools)
   775‚Üí
   776‚Üí        # Create request record (parent_id will be set later)
   777‚Üí        record_id = record.get("id", "")
   778‚Üí        timestamp = _iso_to_unix_ms(record.get("timestamp", ""))
   779‚Üí        model = request.get("model", "")
   780‚Üí        duration_ms = record.get("duration_ms", 0)
   781‚Üí
   782‚Üí        return CookedRequest(
   783‚Üí            id=record_id,
   784‚Üí            parent_id=None,
   785‚Üí            timestamp=timestamp,
   786‚Üí            request_messages=request_msg_ids,
   787‚Üí            response_message=response_msg_id,
   788‚Üí            model=model,
   789‚Üí            tools=tool_ids,
   790‚Üí            duration_ms=duration_ms,
   791‚Üí        )
   792‚Üí
   793‚Üí    def cook(self, records: list[dict], api_format: str = "auto") -> CookedOutput:
   794‚Üí        """Process all records and return deduplicated output."""
   795‚Üí        # Step 1: Process all records
   796‚Üí        for record in records:
   797‚Üí            cooked_request = self._process_record(record, api_format)
   798‚Üí            self.requests.append(cooked_request)
   799‚Üí
   800‚Üí        # Step 2: Sort by timestamp
   801‚Üí        self.requests.sort(key=lambda r: r.timestamp)
   802‚Üí
   803‚Üí        # Step 3: Analyze dependencies
   804‚Üí        self._analyze_dependencies()
   805‚Üí
   806‚Üí        return CookedOutput(
   807‚Üí            messages=self.messages,
   808‚Üí            tools=self.tools,
   809‚Üí            requests=self.requests,
   810‚Üí        )
   811‚Üí
   812‚Üí    # Dependency analysis parameters
   813‚Üí    TOOL_DIFF_PENALTY = 0.5  # Penalty per different tool
   814‚Üí    RELATIVE_THRESHOLD = 0.5  # Edit distance threshold as ratio of message count
   815‚Üí
   816‚Üí    def _analyze_dependencies(self) -> None:
   817‚Üí        """Analyze request dependencies and set parent_id for each request."""
   818‚Üí        for idx, req in enumerate(self.requests):
   819‚Üí            if idx == 0:
   820‚Üí                req.parent_id = None
   821‚Üí            else:
   822‚Üí                req.parent_id = self._find_parent(req, self.requests[:idx])
   823‚Üí
   824‚Üí    def _find_parent(self, curr: CookedRequest, candidates: list[CookedRequest]) -> str | None:
   825‚Üí        """Find the best parent for current request.
   826‚Üí
   827‚Üí        Args:
   828‚Üí            curr: Current request
   829‚Üí            candidates: Requests earlier than curr (sorted by timestamp ascending)
   830‚Üí
   831‚Üí        Returns:
   832‚Üí            parent_id or None (becomes new root if no good match)
   833‚Üí        """
   834‚Üí        # Filter: only consider candidates with same model
   835‚Üí        same_model_candidates = [c for c in candidates if c.model == curr.model]
   836‚Üí
   837‚Üí        if not same_model_candidates:
   838‚Üí            return None  # No same-model candidate, become new root
   839‚Üí
   840‚Üí        # Optimization: check prefix relationship first (from most recent)
   841‚Üí        for c in reversed(same_model_candidates):
   842‚Üí            expected_prefix = self._build_expected_prefix(c)
   843‚Üí            if self._is_prefix(expected_prefix, curr.request_messages):
   844‚Üí                return c.id
   845‚Üí
   846‚Üí        # Fallback: use combined score to find most similar parent
   847‚Üí        best_score = float("-inf")
   848‚Üí        best_parent_id = None
   849‚Üí
   850‚Üí        for c in reversed(same_model_candidates):  # From most recent, same score picks latest
   851‚Üí            score = self._match_score(curr, c)
   852‚Üí            if score > best_score:
   853‚Üí                best_score = score
   854‚Üí                best_parent_id = c.id
   855‚Üí
   856‚Üí        # Forest support: become new root if score is too low
   857‚Üí        threshold = -len(curr.request_messages) * self.RELATIVE_THRESHOLD
   858‚Üí        if best_score < threshold:
   859‚Üí            return None
   860‚Üí
   861‚Üí        return best_parent_id
   862‚Üí
   863‚Üí    def _build_expected_prefix(self, candidate: CookedRequest) -> list[str]:
   864‚Üí        """Build expected message prefix.
   865‚Üí
   866‚Üí        If candidate has response_message, prefix = request_messages + [response_message]
   867‚Üí        Otherwise just request_messages
   868‚Üí        """
   869‚Üí        prefix = list(candidate.request_messages)
   870‚Üí        if candidate.response_message is not None:
   871‚Üí            prefix.append(candidate.response_message)
   872‚Üí        return prefix
   873‚Üí
   874‚Üí    def _is_prefix(self, prefix: list[str], messages: list[str]) -> bool:
   875‚Üí        """Check if prefix is a prefix of messages."""
   876‚Üí        if len(prefix) > len(messages):
   877‚Üí            return False
   878‚Üí        return messages[: len(prefix)] == prefix
   879‚Üí
   880‚Üí    def _match_score(self, curr: CookedRequest, candidate: CookedRequest) -> float:
   881‚Üí        """Compute combined match score (higher is more similar).
   882‚Üí
   883‚Üí        Score = message_score + tool_score
   884‚Üí        - message_score: negative edit distance
   885‚Üí        - tool_score: penalty for tool differences
   886‚Üí        """
   887‚Üí        # Message score: negative edit distance
   888‚Üí        a = self._build_expected_prefix(candidate)
   889‚Üí        b = curr.request_messages
   890‚Üí        message_score = -self._levenshtein(a, b)
   891‚Üí
   892‚Üí        # Tool score: penalty for different tools
   893‚Üí        curr_tools = set(curr.tools)
   894‚Üí        candidate_tools = set(candidate.tools)
   895‚Üí        tool_diff = len(curr_tools.symmetric_difference(candidate_tools))
   896‚Üí        tool_score = -self.TOOL_DIFF_PENALTY * tool_diff
   897‚Üí
   898‚Üí        return message_score + tool_score
   899‚Üí
   900‚Üí    def _levenshtein(self, a: list[str], b: list[str]) -> int:
   901‚Üí        """Compute Levenshtein distance between two lists.
   902‚Üí
   903‚Üí        Operations: add, delete, replace
   904‚Üí        """
   905‚Üí        m, n = len(a), len(b)
   906‚Üí        dp = [[0] * (n + 1) for _ in range(m + 1)]
   907‚Üí
   908‚Üí        for i in range(m + 1):
   909‚Üí            dp[i][0] = i
   910‚Üí        for j in range(n + 1):
   911‚Üí            dp[0][j] = j
   912‚Üí
   913‚Üí        for i in range(1, m + 1):
   914‚Üí            for j in range(1, n + 1):
   915‚Üí                if a[i - 1] == b[j - 1]:
   916‚Üí                    dp[i][j] = dp[i - 1][j - 1]
   917‚Üí                else:
   918‚Üí                    dp[i][j] = 1 + min(
   919‚Üí                        dp[i - 1][j],  # delete
   920‚Üí                        dp[i][j - 1],  # add
   921‚Üí                        dp[i - 1][j - 1],  # replace
   922‚Üí                    )
   923‚Üí
   924‚Üí        return dp[m][n]
   925‚Üí
   926‚Üí
   927‚Üídef cook_traces(input_path: str, output_path: str, api_format: str = "auto") -> None:
   928‚Üí    """Main entry point: read JSONL/JSON traces and write cooked JSON output.
   929‚Üí
   930‚Üí    Args:
   931‚Üí        input_path: Path to input JSONL/JSON trace file
   932‚Üí        output_path: Path to output JSON file
   933‚Üí        api_format: API format of input traces: "auto", "openai", or "claude"
   934‚Üí    """
   935‚Üí    input_file = Path(input_path)
   936‚Üí    output_file = Path(output_path)
   937‚Üí
   938‚Üí    # Read records
   939‚Üí    records = []
   940‚Üí    content = input_file.read_text(encoding="utf-8")
   941‚Üí
   942‚Üí    # Try to parse as JSON array first (single JSON file)
   943‚Üí    try:
   944‚Üí        data = json.loads(content)
   945‚Üí        if isinstance(data, list):
   946‚Üí            records = data
   947‚Üí        else:
   948‚Üí            # Single record
   949‚Üí            records = [data]
   950‚Üí    except json.JSONDecodeError:
   951‚Üí        # Parse as JSONL
   952‚Üí        for line in content.strip().split("\n"):
   953‚Üí            if line.strip():
   954‚Üí                records.append(json.loads(line))
   955‚Üí
   956‚Üí    # Process records
   957‚Üí    cooker = TraceCooker()
   958‚Üí    output = cooker.cook(records, api_format)
   959‚Üí
   960‚Üí    # Write output
   961‚Üí    output_file.parent.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
   962‚Üí    with open(output_file, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
   963‚Üí        json.dump(output.to_dict(), f, ensure_ascii=False, indent=2)
   964‚Üí
   965‚Üí    print(f"Processed {len(records)} records")
   966‚Üí    print(f"  Messages: {len(output.messages)} (deduplicated)")
   967‚Üí    print(f"  Tools: {len(output.tools)} (deduplicated)")
   968‚Üí    print(f"  Requests: {len(output.requests)}")
   969‚Üí    print(f"Output written to: {output_path}")
   970‚Üí

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

tools.name: Bash
tools.description:
Executes a given bash command with optional timeout. Working directory persists between commands; shell state (everything else) does not. The shell environment is initialized from the user's profile (bash or zsh).

IMPORTANT: This tool is for terminal operations like git, npm, docker, etc. DO NOT use it for file operations (reading, writing, editing, searching, finding files) - use the specialized tools for this instead.

Before executing the command, please follow these steps:

1. Directory Verification:
   - If the command will create new directories or files, first use `ls` to verify the parent directory exists and is the correct location
   - For example, before running "mkdir foo/bar", first use `ls foo` to check that "foo" exists and is the intended parent directory

2. Command Execution:
   - Always quote file paths that contain spaces with double quotes (e.g., cd "path with spaces/file.txt")
   - Examples of proper quoting:
     - cd "/Users/name/My Documents" (correct)
     - cd /Users/name/My Documents (incorrect - will fail)
     - python "/path/with spaces/script.py" (correct)
     - python /path/with spaces/script.py (incorrect - will fail)
   - After ensuring proper quoting, execute the command.
   - Capture the output of the command.

Usage notes:
  - The command argument is required.
  - You can specify an optional timeout in milliseconds (up to 600000ms / 10 minutes). If not specified, commands will timeout after 120000ms (2 minutes).
  - It is very helpful if you write a clear, concise description of what this command does. For simple commands, keep it brief (5-10 words). For complex commands (piped commands, obscure flags, or anything hard to understand at a glance), add enough context to clarify what it does.
  - If the output exceeds 30000 characters, output will be truncated before being returned to you.
  
  - You can use the `run_in_background` parameter to run the command in the background. Only use this if you don't need the result immediately and are OK being notified when the command completes later. You do not need to check the output right away - you'll be notified when it finishes. You do not need to use '&' at the end of the command when using this parameter.
  
  - Avoid using Bash with the `find`, `grep`, `cat`, `head`, `tail`, `sed`, `awk`, or `echo` commands, unless explicitly instructed or when these commands are truly necessary for the task. Instead, always prefer using the dedicated tools for these commands:
    - File search: Use Glob (NOT find or ls)
    - Content search: Use Grep (NOT grep or rg)
    - Read files: Use Read (NOT cat/head/tail)
    - Edit files: Use Edit (NOT sed/awk)
    - Write files: Use Write (NOT echo >/cat <<EOF)
    - Communication: Output text directly (NOT echo/printf)
  - When issuing multiple commands:
    - If the commands are independent and can run in parallel, make multiple Bash tool calls in a single message. For example, if you need to run "git status" and "git diff", send a single message with two Bash tool calls in parallel.
    - If the commands depend on each other and must run sequentially, use a single Bash call with '&&' to chain them together (e.g., `git add . && git commit -m "message" && git push`). For instance, if one operation must complete before another starts (like mkdir before cp, Write before Bash for git operations, or git add before git commit), run these operations sequentially instead.
    - Use ';' only when you need to run commands sequentially but don't care if earlier commands fail
    - DO NOT use newlines to separate commands (newlines are ok in quoted strings)
  - Try to maintain your current working directory throughout the session by using absolute paths and avoiding usage of `cd`. You may use `cd` if the User explicitly requests it.
    <good-example>
    pytest /foo/bar/tests
    </good-example>
    <bad-example>
    cd /foo/bar && pytest tests
    </bad-example>

# Committing changes with git

Only create commits when requested by the user. If unclear, ask first. When the user asks you to create a new git commit, follow these steps carefully:

Git Safety Protocol:
- NEVER update the git config
- NEVER run destructive git commands (push --force, reset --hard, checkout ., restore ., clean -f, branch -D) unless the user explicitly requests these actions. Taking unauthorized destructive actions is unhelpful and can result in lost work, so it's best to ONLY run these commands when given direct instructions 
- NEVER skip hooks (--no-verify, --no-gpg-sign, etc) unless the user explicitly requests it
- NEVER run force push to main/master, warn the user if they request it
- CRITICAL: Always create NEW commits rather than amending, unless the user explicitly requests a git amend. When a pre-commit hook fails, the commit did NOT happen ‚Äî so --amend would modify the PREVIOUS commit, which may result in destroying work or losing previous changes. Instead, after hook failure, fix the issue, re-stage, and create a NEW commit
- When staging files, prefer adding specific files by name rather than using "git add -A" or "git add .", which can accidentally include sensitive files (.env, credentials) or large binaries
- NEVER commit changes unless the user explicitly asks you to. It is VERY IMPORTANT to only commit when explicitly asked, otherwise the user will feel that you are being too proactive

1. You can call multiple tools in a single response. When multiple independent pieces of information are requested and all commands are likely to succeed, run multiple tool calls in parallel for optimal performance. run the following bash commands in parallel, each using the Bash tool:
  - Run a git status command to see all untracked files. IMPORTANT: Never use the -uall flag as it can cause memory issues on large repos.
  - Run a git diff command to see both staged and unstaged changes that will be committed.
  - Run a git log command to see recent commit messages, so that you can follow this repository's commit message style.
2. Analyze all staged changes (both previously staged and newly added) and draft a commit message:
  - Summarize the nature of the changes (eg. new feature, enhancement to an existing feature, bug fix, refactoring, test, docs, etc.). Ensure the message accurately reflects the changes and their purpose (i.e. "add" means a wholly new feature, "update" means an enhancement to an existing feature, "fix" means a bug fix, etc.).
  - Do not commit files that likely contain secrets (.env, credentials.json, etc). Warn the user if they specifically request to commit those files
  - Draft a concise (1-2 sentences) commit message that focuses on the "why" rather than the "what"
  - Ensure it accurately reflects the changes and their purpose
3. You can call multiple tools in a single response. When multiple independent pieces of information are requested and all commands are likely to succeed, run multiple tool calls in parallel for optimal performance. run the following commands:
   - Add relevant untracked files to the staging area.
   - Create the commit with a message ending with:
   Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
   - Run git status after the commit completes to verify success.
   Note: git status depends on the commit completing, so run it sequentially after the commit.
4. If the commit fails due to pre-commit hook: fix the issue and create a NEW commit

Important notes:
- NEVER run additional commands to read or explore code, besides git bash commands
- NEVER use the TodoWrite or Task tools
- DO NOT push to the remote repository unless the user explicitly asks you to do so
- IMPORTANT: Never use git commands with the -i flag (like git rebase -i or git add -i) since they require interactive input which is not supported.
- IMPORTANT: Do not use --no-edit with git rebase commands, as the --no-edit flag is not a valid option for git rebase.
- If there are no changes to commit (i.e., no untracked files and no modifications), do not create an empty commit
- In order to ensure good formatting, ALWAYS pass the commit message via a HEREDOC, a la this example:
<example>
git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
   Commit message here.

   Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
   EOF
   )"
</example>

# Creating pull requests
Use the gh command via the Bash tool for ALL GitHub-related tasks including working with issues, pull requests, checks, and releases. If given a Github URL use the gh command to get the information needed.

IMPORTANT: When the user asks you to create a pull request, follow these steps carefully:

1. You can call multiple tools in a single response. When multiple independent pieces of information are requested and all commands are likely to succeed, run multiple tool calls in parallel for optimal performance. run the following bash commands in parallel using the Bash tool, in order to understand the current state of the branch since it diverged from the main branch:
   - Run a git status command to see all untracked files (never use -uall flag)
   - Run a git diff command to see both staged and unstaged changes that will be committed
   - Check if the current branch tracks a remote branch and is up to date with the remote, so you know if you need to push to the remote
   - Run a git log command and `git diff [base-branch]...HEAD` to understand the full commit history for the current branch (from the time it diverged from the base branch)
2. Analyze all changes that will be included in the pull request, making sure to look at all relevant commits (NOT just the latest commit, but ALL commits that will be included in the pull request!!!), and draft a pull request title and summary:
   - Keep the PR title short (under 70 characters)
   - Use the description/body for details, not the title
3. You can call multiple tools in a single response. When multiple independent pieces of information are requested and all commands are likely to succeed, run multiple tool calls in parallel for optimal performance. run the following commands in parallel:
   - Create new branch if needed
   - Push to remote with -u flag if needed
   - Create PR using gh pr create with the format below. Use a HEREDOC to pass the body to ensure correct formatting.
<example>
gh pr create --title "the pr title" --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Summary
<1-3 bullet points>

## Test plan
[Bulleted markdown checklist of TODOs for testing the pull request...]

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)
EOF
)"
</example>

Important:
- DO NOT use the TodoWrite or Task tools
- Return the PR URL when you're done, so the user can see it

# Other common operations
- View comments on a Github PR: gh api repos/foo/bar/pulls/123/comments

description.description:
Clear, concise description of what this command does in active voice. Never use words like "complex" or "risk" in the description - just describe what it does.

For simple commands (git, npm, standard CLI tools), keep it brief (5-10 words):
- ls ‚Üí "List files in current directory"
- git status ‚Üí "Show working tree status"
- npm install ‚Üí "Install package dependencies"

For commands that are harder to parse at a glance (piped commands, obscure flags, etc.), add enough context to clarify what it does:
- find . -name "*.tmp" -exec rm {} \; ‚Üí "Find and delete all .tmp files recursively"
- git reset --hard origin/main ‚Üí "Discard all local changes and match remote main"
- curl -s url | jq '.data[]' ‚Üí "Fetch JSON from URL and extract data array elements"

run_in_background.description: Set to true to run this command in the background. Use TaskOutput to read the output later.

dangerouslyDisableSandbox.description: Set this to true to dangerously override sandbox mode and run commands without sandboxing.

tools.name: Glob
tools.description:
- Fast file pattern matching tool that works with any codebase size
- Supports glob patterns like "**/*.js" or "src/**/*.ts"
- Returns matching file paths sorted by modification time
- Use this tool when you need to find files by name patterns
- When you are doing an open ended search that may require multiple rounds of globbing and grepping, use the Agent tool instead
- You can call multiple tools in a single response. It is always better to speculatively perform multiple searches in parallel if they are potentially useful.

pattern.description: The glob pattern to match files against

path.description: The directory to search in. If not specified, the current working directory will be used. IMPORTANT: Omit this field to use the default directory. DO NOT enter "undefined" or "null" - simply omit it for the default behavior. Must be a valid directory path if provided.

tools.name: Grep
tools.description:
A powerful search tool built on ripgrep

  Usage:
  - ALWAYS use Grep for search tasks. NEVER invoke `grep` or `rg` as a Bash command. The Grep tool has been optimized for correct permissions and access.
  - Supports full regex syntax (e.g., "log.*Error", "function\s+\w+")
  - Filter files with glob parameter (e.g., "*.js", "**/*.tsx") or type parameter (e.g., "js", "py", "rust")
  - Output modes: "content" shows matching lines, "files_with_matches" shows only file paths (default), "count" shows match counts
  - Use Task tool for open-ended searches requiring multiple rounds
  - Pattern syntax: Uses ripgrep (not grep) - literal braces need escaping (use `interface\{\}` to find `interface{}` in Go code)
  - Multiline matching: By default patterns match within single lines only. For cross-line patterns like `struct \{[\s\S]*?field`, use `multiline: true`

pattern.description: The regular expression pattern to search for in file contents

path.description: File or directory to search in (rg PATH). Defaults to current working directory.

glob.description: Glob pattern to filter files (e.g. "*.js", "*.{ts,tsx}") - maps to rg --glob

output_mode.description: Output mode: "content" shows matching lines (supports -A/-B/-C context, -n line numbers, head_limit), "files_with_matches" shows file paths (supports head_limit), "count" shows match counts (supports head_limit). Defaults to "files_with_matches".

-B.description: Number of lines to show before each match (rg -B). Requires output_mode: "content", ignored otherwise.

-A.description: Number of lines to show after each match (rg -A). Requires output_mode: "content", ignored otherwise.

context.description: Number of lines to show before and after each match (rg -C). Requires output_mode: "content", ignored otherwise.

-n.description: Show line numbers in output (rg -n). Requires output_mode: "content", ignored otherwise. Defaults to true.

type.description: File type to search (rg --type). Common types: js, py, rust, go, java, etc. More efficient than include for standard file types.

head_limit.description: Limit output to first N lines/entries, equivalent to "| head -N". Works across all output modes: content (limits output lines), files_with_matches (limits file paths), count (limits count entries). Defaults to 0 (unlimited).

offset.description: Skip first N lines/entries before applying head_limit, equivalent to "| tail -n +N | head -N". Works across all output modes. Defaults to 0.

multiline.description: Enable multiline mode where . matches newlines and patterns can span lines (rg -U --multiline-dotall). Default: false.

tools.name: Read
tools.description:
Reads a file from the local filesystem. You can access any file directly by using this tool.
Assume this tool is able to read all files on the machine. If the User provides a path to a file assume that path is valid. It is okay to read a file that does not exist; an error will be returned.

Usage:
- The file_path parameter must be an absolute path, not a relative path
- By default, it reads up to 2000 lines starting from the beginning of the file
- You can optionally specify a line offset and limit (especially handy for long files), but it's recommended to read the whole file by not providing these parameters
- Any lines longer than 2000 characters will be truncated
- Results are returned using cat -n format, with line numbers starting at 1
- This tool allows Claude Code to read images (eg PNG, JPG, etc). When reading an image file the contents are presented visually as Claude Code is a multimodal LLM.
- This tool can read PDF files (.pdf). For large PDFs (more than 10 pages), you MUST provide the pages parameter to read specific page ranges (e.g., pages: "1-5"). Reading a large PDF without the pages parameter will fail. Maximum 20 pages per request.
- This tool can read Jupyter notebooks (.ipynb files) and returns all cells with their outputs, combining code, text, and visualizations.
- This tool can only read files, not directories. To read a directory, use an ls command via the Bash tool.
- You can call multiple tools in a single response. It is always better to speculatively read multiple potentially useful files in parallel.
- You will regularly be asked to read screenshots. If the user provides a path to a screenshot, ALWAYS use this tool to view the file at the path. This tool will work with all temporary file paths.
- If you read a file that exists but has empty contents you will receive a system reminder warning in place of file contents.

file_path.description: The absolute path to the file to read

offset.description: The line number to start reading from. Only provide if the file is too large to read at once

limit.description: The number of lines to read. Only provide if the file is too large to read at once.

pages.description: Page range for PDF files (e.g., "1-5", "3", "10-20"). Only applicable to PDF files. Maximum 20 pages per request.

tools.name: Edit
tools.description:
Performs exact string replacements in files.

Usage:
- You must use your `Read` tool at least once in the conversation before editing. This tool will error if you attempt an edit without reading the file. 
- When editing text from Read tool output, ensure you preserve the exact indentation (tabs/spaces) as it appears AFTER the line number prefix. The line number prefix format is: spaces + line number + tab. Everything after that tab is the actual file content to match. Never include any part of the line number prefix in the old_string or new_string.
- ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required.
- Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it. Avoid adding emojis to files unless asked.
- The edit will FAIL if `old_string` is not unique in the file. Either provide a larger string with more surrounding context to make it unique or use `replace_all` to change every instance of `old_string`.
- Use `replace_all` for replacing and renaming strings across the file. This parameter is useful if you want to rename a variable for instance.

file_path.description: The absolute path to the file to modify

new_string.description: The text to replace it with (must be different from old_string)

replace_all.description: Replace all occurrences of old_string (default false)

tools.name: Write
tools.description:
Writes a file to the local filesystem.

Usage:
- This tool will overwrite the existing file if there is one at the provided path.
- If this is an existing file, you MUST use the Read tool first to read the file's contents. This tool will fail if you did not read the file first.
- ALWAYS prefer editing existing files in the codebase. NEVER write new files unless explicitly required.
- NEVER proactively create documentation files (*.md) or README files. Only create documentation files if explicitly requested by the User.
- Only use emojis if the user explicitly requests it. Avoid writing emojis to files unless asked.

file_path.description: The absolute path to the file to write (must be absolute, not relative)

content.description: The content to write to the file

tools.name: NotebookEdit
tools.description: Completely replaces the contents of a specific cell in a Jupyter notebook (.ipynb file) with new source. Jupyter notebooks are interactive documents that combine code, text, and visualizations, commonly used for data analysis and scientific computing. The notebook_path parameter must be an absolute path, not a relative path. The cell_number is 0-indexed. Use edit_mode=insert to add a new cell at the index specified by cell_number. Use edit_mode=delete to delete the cell at the index specified by cell_number.

notebook_path.description: The absolute path to the Jupyter notebook file to edit (must be absolute, not relative)

cell_id.description: The ID of the cell to edit. When inserting a new cell, the new cell will be inserted after the cell with this ID, or at the beginning if not specified.

new_source.description: The new source for the cell

cell_type.description: The type of the cell (code or markdown). If not specified, it defaults to the current cell type. If using edit_mode=insert, this is required.

edit_mode.description: The type of edit to make (replace, insert, delete). Defaults to replace.

tools.name: WebFetch
tools.description:
IMPORTANT: WebFetch WILL FAIL for authenticated or private URLs. Before using this tool, check if the URL points to an authenticated service (e.g. Google Docs, Confluence, Jira, GitHub). If so, you MUST use ToolSearch first to find a specialized tool that provides authenticated access.

- Fetches content from a specified URL and processes it using an AI model
- Takes a URL and a prompt as input
- Fetches the URL content, converts HTML to markdown
- Processes the content with the prompt using a small, fast model
- Returns the model's response about the content
- Use this tool when you need to retrieve and analyze web content

Usage notes:
  - IMPORTANT: If an MCP-provided web fetch tool is available, prefer using that tool instead of this one, as it may have fewer restrictions.
  - The URL must be a fully-formed valid URL
  - HTTP URLs will be automatically upgraded to HTTPS
  - The prompt should describe what information you want to extract from the page
  - This tool is read-only and does not modify any files
  - Results may be summarized if the content is very large
  - Includes a self-cleaning 15-minute cache for faster responses when repeatedly accessing the same URL
  - When a URL redirects to a different host, the tool will inform you and provide the redirect URL in a special format. You should then make a new WebFetch request with the redirect URL to fetch the content.
  - For GitHub URLs, prefer using the gh CLI via Bash instead (e.g., gh pr view, gh issue view, gh api).

url.description: The URL to fetch content from

prompt.description: The prompt to run on the fetched content

tools.name: WebSearch
tools.description:
- Allows Claude to search the web and use the results to inform responses
- Provides up-to-date information for current events and recent data
- Returns search result information formatted as search result blocks, including links as markdown hyperlinks
- Use this tool for accessing information beyond Claude's knowledge cutoff
- Searches are performed automatically within a single API call

CRITICAL REQUIREMENT - You MUST follow this:
  - After answering the user's question, you MUST include a "Sources:" section at the end of your response
  - In the Sources section, list all relevant URLs from the search results as markdown hyperlinks: [Title](URL)
  - This is MANDATORY - never skip including sources in your response
  - Example format:

    [Your answer here]

    Sources:
    - [Source Title 1](https://example.com/1)
    - [Source Title 2](https://example.com/2)

Usage notes:
  - Domain filtering is supported to include or block specific websites
  - Web search is only available in the US

IMPORTANT - Use the correct year in search queries:
  - The current month is February 2026. You MUST use this year when searching for recent information, documentation, or current events.
  - Example: If the user asks for "latest React docs", search for "React documentation" with the current year, NOT last year

allowed_domains.description: Only include search results from these domains

blocked_domains.description: Never include search results from these domains

tools.name: Skill
tools.description:
Execute a skill within the main conversation

When users ask you to perform tasks, check if any of the available skills match. Skills provide specialized capabilities and domain knowledge.

When users reference a "slash command" or "/<something>" (e.g., "/commit", "/review-pr"), they are referring to a skill. Use this tool to invoke it.

How to invoke:
- Use this tool with the skill name and optional arguments
- Examples:
  - `skill: "pdf"` - invoke the pdf skill
  - `skill: "commit", args: "-m 'Fix bug'"` - invoke with arguments
  - `skill: "review-pr", args: "123"` - invoke with arguments
  - `skill: "ms-office-suite:pdf"` - invoke using fully qualified name

Important:
- Available skills are listed in system-reminder messages in the conversation
- When a skill matches the user's request, this is a BLOCKING REQUIREMENT: invoke the relevant Skill tool BEFORE generating any other response about the task
- NEVER mention a skill without actually calling this tool
- Do not invoke a skill that is already running
- Do not use this tool for built-in CLI commands (like /help, /clear, etc.)
- If you see a <command-name> tag in the current conversation turn, the skill has ALREADY been loaded - follow the instructions directly instead of calling this tool again

tools.name: TaskCreate
tools.description:
Use this tool to create a structured task list for your current coding session. This helps you track progress, organize complex tasks, and demonstrate thoroughness to the user.
It also helps the user understand the progress of the task and overall progress of their requests.

## When to Use This Tool

Use this tool proactively in these scenarios:

- Complex multi-step tasks - When a task requires 3 or more distinct steps or actions
- Non-trivial and complex tasks - Tasks that require careful planning or multiple operations
- Plan mode - When using plan mode, create a task list to track the work
- User explicitly requests todo list - When the user directly asks you to use the todo list
- User provides multiple tasks - When users provide a list of things to be done (numbered or comma-separated)
- After receiving new instructions - Immediately capture user requirements as tasks
- When you start working on a task - Mark it as in_progress BEFORE beginning work
- After completing a task - Mark it as completed and add any new follow-up tasks discovered during implementation

## When NOT to Use This Tool

Skip using this tool when:
- There is only a single, straightforward task
- The task is trivial and tracking it provides no organizational benefit
- The task can be completed in less than 3 trivial steps
- The task is purely conversational or informational

NOTE that you should not use this tool if there is only one trivial task to do. In this case you are better off just doing the task directly.

## Task Fields

- **subject**: A brief, actionable title in imperative form (e.g., "Fix authentication bug in login flow")
- **description**: Detailed description of what needs to be done, including context and acceptance criteria
- **activeForm**: Present continuous form shown in spinner when task is in_progress (e.g., "Fixing authentication bug"). This is displayed to the user while you work on the task.

**IMPORTANT**: Always provide activeForm when creating tasks. The subject should be imperative ("Run tests") while activeForm should be present continuous ("Running tests"). All tasks are created with status `pending`.

## Tips

- Create tasks with clear, specific subjects that describe the outcome
- Include enough detail in the description for another agent to understand and complete the task
- After creating tasks, use TaskUpdate to set up dependencies (blocks/blockedBy) if needed
- Check TaskList first to avoid creating duplicate tasks

subject.description: A brief title for the task

description.description: A detailed description of what needs to be done

activeForm.description: Present continuous form shown in spinner when in_progress (e.g., "Running tests")

metadata.description: Arbitrary metadata to attach to the task

tools.name: TaskGet
tools.description:
Use this tool to retrieve a task by its ID from the task list.

## When to Use This Tool

- When you need the full description and context before starting work on a task
- To understand task dependencies (what it blocks, what blocks it)
- After being assigned a task, to get complete requirements

## Output

Returns full task details:
- **subject**: Task title
- **description**: Detailed requirements and context
- **status**: 'pending', 'in_progress', or 'completed'
- **blocks**: Tasks waiting on this one to complete
- **blockedBy**: Tasks that must complete before this one can start

## Tips

- After fetching a task, verify its blockedBy list is empty before beginning work.
- Use TaskList to see all tasks in summary form.

taskId.description: The ID of the task to retrieve

tools.name: TaskUpdate
tools.description:
Use this tool to update a task in the task list.

## When to Use This Tool

**Mark tasks as resolved:**
- When you have completed the work described in a task
- When a task is no longer needed or has been superseded
- IMPORTANT: Always mark your assigned tasks as resolved when you finish them
- After resolving, call TaskList to find your next task

- ONLY mark a task as completed when you have FULLY accomplished it
- If you encounter errors, blockers, or cannot finish, keep the task as in_progress
- When blocked, create a new task describing what needs to be resolved
- Never mark a task as completed if:
  - Tests are failing
  - Implementation is partial
  - You encountered unresolved errors
  - You couldn't find necessary files or dependencies

**Delete tasks:**
- When a task is no longer relevant or was created in error
- Setting status to `deleted` permanently removes the task

**Update task details:**
- When requirements change or become clearer
- When establishing dependencies between tasks

## Fields You Can Update

- **status**: The task status (see Status Workflow below)
- **subject**: Change the task title (imperative form, e.g., "Run tests")
- **description**: Change the task description
- **activeForm**: Present continuous form shown in spinner when in_progress (e.g., "Running tests")
- **owner**: Change the task owner (agent name)
- **metadata**: Merge metadata keys into the task (set a key to null to delete it)
- **addBlocks**: Mark tasks that cannot start until this one completes
- **addBlockedBy**: Mark tasks that must complete before this one can start

## Status Workflow

Status progresses: `pending` ‚Üí `in_progress` ‚Üí `completed`

Use `deleted` to permanently remove a task.

## Staleness

Make sure to read a task's latest state using `TaskGet` before updating it.

## Examples

Mark task as in progress when starting work:
```json
{"taskId": "1", "status": "in_progress"}
```

Mark task as completed after finishing work:
```json
{"taskId": "1", "status": "completed"}
```

Delete a task:
```json
{"taskId": "1", "status": "deleted"}
```

Claim a task by setting owner:
```json
{"taskId": "1", "owner": "my-name"}
```

Set up task dependencies:
```json
{"taskId": "2", "addBlockedBy": ["1"]}
```

taskId.description: The ID of the task to update

subject.description: New subject for the task

description.description: New description for the task

activeForm.description: Present continuous form shown in spinner when in_progress (e.g., "Running tests")

addBlocks.description: Task IDs that this task blocks

addBlockedBy.description: Task IDs that block this task

metadata.description: Metadata keys to merge into the task. Set a key to null to delete it.

tools.name: TaskList
tools.description:
Use this tool to list all tasks in the task list.

## When to Use This Tool

- To see what tasks are available to work on (status: 'pending', no owner, not blocked)
- To check overall progress on the project
- To find tasks that are blocked and need dependencies resolved
- After completing a task, to check for newly unblocked work or claim the next available task
- **Prefer working on tasks in ID order** (lowest ID first) when multiple tasks are available, as earlier tasks often set up context for later ones

## Output

Returns a summary of each task:
- **id**: Task identifier (use with TaskGet, TaskUpdate)
- **subject**: Brief description of the task
- **status**: 'pending', 'in_progress', or 'completed'
- **owner**: Agent ID if assigned, empty if available
- **blockedBy**: List of open task IDs that must be resolved first (tasks with blockedBy cannot be claimed until dependencies resolve)

Use TaskGet with a specific task ID to view full details including description and comments.
